segments.text: real good friends very she took me home to her family and uh her name is maria cough
We did correspond quite a bit.
Maybe that's the one they considered.
She later on became a school teacher.
Maybe she wrote to me, but she became a school teacher.
Not that she...
While I was in camp.
So... That's a good question.
I can't even think to ask who you corresponded with when you did it.
So here's a romance with a girl, and you just got through it, and you went to a tree.
You were recuperating, and you met two girls, or just one?
We met both of them.
We were walking together, both sisters.
Did any of these develop into passionate love affairs, or is it just, I'm trying to figure out how,
rural this is.
Is this holding hands and walking through the park, or is this closeting yourself?
I don't mean to be too straightforward, but I'm trying to figure out the level of your worldliness.
Oh, I would say that I was quite smitten by her beauty and attractiveness, I would say.
She was a very pretty girl and a fun girl.
There's the usual attraction, I mean a good healthy attraction between a young man and a young woman.
It's just that, good, you know, fun.
I'm sure it could have gotten somewhere.
But it didn't.
But it was definitely there.
Oh, sure.
Well, there was another one in Berlin that I was kind of also very attracted to.

But while I was in camp, and I also got letters from her in camp, so it wasn't, that's why I always said, you know, this one girl thing that was mentioned in these articles didn't quite gel, because if you're engaged, you don't write to two or three others.
I mean, I never felt engaged in that sense.
But I...
The other one that I was
also attracted to, like a young man being attracted to a number of young, attractive ladies.
And if you're trying to reach the level, I would have to fess up.
That was quite worldly.
Oh, good.
Good.
All right.
I don't mean it as a value judgment or anything like that.
I'm not trying to hedge either and make something out of something.
I'm trying to get to the truth myself, because what do I know?
I just do it.
Pardon me.
When, how do I put this in a more delicate way, when did you find somebody
Budapest had the first what, Spanbridge?
U-Bahn.
Oh yes, the subway.
Subway, before Vienna.
Yes, oh yes.
Hungary had a... U-Bahn.
Hungary had a beautiful Victorian mosaic on the walls.
Really?
Yeah, just lovely.
And it's the biggest span bridge in the world up to that moment.
It was built across the Danube, and it was built by Whistler's father.
Everybody hears about Whistler's mother.
Nobody ever hears about Whistler's father.
He was a famous architect.
The same family?
Same family.
Whistler's father was a bridge builder.
He built the huge span bridge across the Danube in Hungary.
And I think he also contributed to the Golden Gate Bridge once.
Really?
Yes.
I mentioned that in the early days, that was right after Poland and Hungary, I guess, as we talked yesterday, these were all blitzkriegs.
In other words, they went in, they didn't last more than a week and a half, really, two months, I don't know.
But certainly not a drawn-out,
Search and destroy kind of operation.
Yeah, it's like Vietnam.
Yeah, where everything is in shambles, you know.
Okay, anyway.
Let me ask you about, all right, so you have some girlfriends and love affairs, and they eventually, letters followed you even to the POW camp.
The other one that I... She married your best friend.
She married...
She married a doctor.
I've got letters saying that she now had two children or something like that.
She married a doctor.
Gene is laughing to herself at how adolescent men are.
Then, let's see, while we're at it, I'm just trying to open up a hedge on that romance department.
I was just curious when you found a man...
I'm going to ask this question.
Why don't we get to it?
Marry the Oberlieutenant.
What?
Marry the Oberlieutenant.
I'm just trying to find out how worldly you were when you first met a girl and went to bed with this girl.
This was hard.
When did you go to bed with somebody?
And the reason I ask is because, one, I'm trying to assess the worldliness.
The isolation up until you were with Jean, too.
The question of how much contact were you having?
How much of a survivor were you?
How much of a loner were you?

If, for instance, nothing had happened until after you got out of the prison camp, or something like that, or even into your 30s or 40s, that means that you were putting a lot more energy on being alone and safe.
No, I think I was quite interested in the opposite sex.
90% of the time.
Oh, sure, sure.
I've asked him a lot of those questions, too, and I get just as little response as yours.
And he thinks I'm doing that out of just curiosity.
I'm not.
Curiosity, yes.
But I was much more interested to find out what his level of intimacy, how was he able to, was he able...
in his earlier days to open up to somebody and have a degree of intimacy then.
And it was important to me to find that out.
Was it just me?
He was unable to get down to this certain level of how time is almost important in a relationship.
And I have not, to this point, been able to get much of a description about how he was with other people.
Well, Chris, in your case, there's two answers to this.
In your answer... No, this doesn't have to be in it at all.
This doesn't have to be... No, no, it's more to understand how much of a loner you had been up to that time.
I took...
I really learned a lot, or thought I learned a lot from the Turk as far as women is concerned.
One of the things that Lowell and I, we were absolutely fascinated by the Turk.
Lowell?
Lowell Welch, yeah.
Lowell Welch.
Lowell Welch, yeah.
Got it.
Absolutely fascinated by this Turk, which is another story sometime if you need an interesting character to liven up a few pages.
Sure.
I got into trouble with him once because I mentioned one of his other girlfriends in the same room with the one that he was with.
The only time he ever got mad at me was, you do not ever mention other girls in front of your girl.
It's an absolute no-no.
No matter how many times they ask you, they want to know all about it, you do not tell.
Which your father told you too, saying that gentlemen don't discuss those things.
This kind of clinical approach, you know, is from the old school, is rejected by the old school of the old macho school, the old bull and jumping over the fence school, you see.
So I came from the old... Oh, I understand that.
And it's not that it needs even any explanation.
There's no judgment to it, of course.
I was just curious whether...
It first became intimate later in life or earlier in life.
Yeah, I understand.
I knew this was always going to be a difficult area.
Oh, I don't mean to make it difficult.
Just later in life would be... No, no.
Okay, then it would be that girl that married the doctor.
Because I had met her when I visited my cousins in Berlin.
And we were out at the Tegernsee, I think.
She knew some friends, and we went out for an afternoon of sailing.
And this gal was there with somebody.
And it turned out she lived fairly close.
She lived in Breslau rather than in Berlin.
She was also a musician there.
So we dated after that, and we did
In fact, I spent a weekend at the ski lodge up there together.
So that was about the hottest romance I had, besides the one from afar.
So I was quite active in my imagination.
reality, I've heard.
And this was between the Jesus and he bent over good again.
That's the way I believe it.

Well, I was curious, you know, if you did have passionate relationships while you were still in Germany, then you took off, was it on dry spell until Jim, or did you manage to have encounters with him in between?
Oh, yes, yes.
We're not talking about intent and motivation.
Alright, so you were on furlough, you were recovering.
On furlough and recovery, how did you get from there to the training, the Army training, official Army training?
Your wound, your shin healed.
Yeah, yeah.
And then eventually you got to go into the Army itself.
Yeah.
Then I was transferred to the West, to Monheim.
There was another training, and that's where I was a drill instructor.
It must have been a major training center.
It's near a railroad, a huge railroad area, where they probably came through and picked them up.
We had constantly new units to train that had gone to different fronts.
Oh, I probably, but within the next couple of weeks, I'm going to have graduate students.
You're going to get them better than you think.
Graduate students who are going to be out looking for them.
training camps in Germany in 1941, what they looked like, how big they were, what trains they served them.
You're probably going to get a lot of these records at times, more typed down than I can.
Lots of pages on that soul book that I have a little difficulty deciphering, because I don't see any mention of Heidelberg.
It must be another, it may be just an assignment I was assigned to this school, I don't know.
Yeah, I noticed there's no photograph in there either.
They used to have a photograph in there.
Maybe it was pulled out.
That may well have been the photograph that was used for your father's photograph.
I thought there was one taken out of the kin carton.
There was that other little thing I showed you.
Besides the soul book, we had a kin carton, an identification.
That had a picture, and that was taken out, I think.
So you went, you were a regular army, you were in Mannheim at the training camp, you were a drill instructor, were you also a ski instructor, or that was it, earlier?
That must have been earlier, because I was still in the eastern part, I was assigned to teaching skiing.
That was when you were in the labor?
No, I was, when I was in the basic training, either in this, might have been with, when I was still with the horses,
It seems to me I was in two places in East Germany before I was shipped to West Germany.
And one of them in East Germany, because there was no snow, so it had to be, and I trained cross-country for Russian front.
Right.
Then to Mannheim, then the drill instructor.
And then you were recycled again and again as a drill instructor as each unit went through.
Were you feared as a drill instructor?
Did you take it very seriously, or was it more just a job or a game?
Well, I like to think that I was a good one.
I mean, a successful one.
I could teach people what it is to do things easier and better.
I try to act as tough and act like I was supposed to act as a drill instructor, but also have a lot of humanities in it, in my unit, and was always finished first or second.
We had competition amongst drill instructors, so I was fairly successful.
If we were to talk to a member of that unit today, and he was to look back and say, I was at Mannheim, I was under Sergeant Gertner,
Boy, what would he say?
What would he say?
This guy didn't give us a break.
He ran us ragged.
It would be fun to find out.
I would like to know myself.
I'd like to think that I was just simply have a good voice.
I think sometimes... How would he describe you?
I don't know how he would describe me, but I'd like...
If I had to...

analyze my approach that I have always used, whether it was a drill instructor or a ski instructor or whatever, to motivate other people to do things that I want them to do, was always to find that certain compromise between toughness and fairness.
And maybe just a little curl around the lips for a little joke on them, too.
I see.
If you were, could you imagine yourself?
Get the hell out of here kind of thing, you know.
If you were, could see yourself as a member of that group today, how would you think you would look back on old Sarge Gardner?
I'd be very happy with him.
You think that he prepared them?
Do you think that Gartner prepared you for combat, wherever you went?
You went off with a spirit, or you went off... You know, when we talk about combat, whatever their weaponry was, I thought I did a good job.
But whether that, you know, the actual application, I don't know.
Like, if you knew how to ski in Russia, certainly it was an advantage to you.
If you knew certain steps that other people didn't know, I can get away from you where the other guy can't.
So I always felt skills is going to be your survival, no matter where you are.
To improve your skills, to pay attention, to look alive, that's all we really did, to kind of shake him up and, you know,
you paying attention?
Are you with me?
You know, type of thing.
Because half of them, I'm sure, didn't want to be there.
Did you?
Well, it seemed like, yeah, I wanted to be there because the alternatives, there were no alternatives.
I couldn't be home.
So, you know, if you give me an alternative, attractive alternatives, maybe, but there were none.
When did you want to become an officer?
Well, I
You know, came from, like I said, from an area that had a lot of tradition in the military, and of course wanted to be an officer badly.
And all, in my school, you know, as soon as you graduated, you were sent automatically to officer school.
My other friend, Horst Trispel, was already an officer.
So, and of course, we had the Prussian
tradition of famous officers.
My hometown, Manfred von Richthofen was born.
I saw his, I met his mother, saw his plane.
The Red Baron.
Numerous generals.
I mean, so it's a militaristic, it's almost the yonkers, what they call.
Oh, another friend I should mention at that point, when I say yonkers, he sat behind me in class.
His name is Von Lieres.
L-I-E-R-E-S.
Von Lieres.
And I guess you would describe him as a yonker.
Actually, what he was, they...
they owned land.
These, these von, von Richthofen, most of them, there were some poor ones and there were some not so poor ones, you know, depending on which land they owned.
And, so, and he liked me and he would ask me to come out to his estate and if you had time you could look through Middle Schlesien and you see what these places look like.
They're big,
farmhouses, you see, those so-called estates.
They have chicken, cows, and the whole thing, plus so many acres, and they raise, they might have farmers that work there.
What is that called?
Other people.
They sub it out.
Tenant farmers.
Yeah, tenant farmers.
So certainly it's a big tradition, a Yonker tradition.
It's a big Yonker tradition.
So Von Lear is this fellow and I.
He used to invite me out for the weekend.
And it's just a great big family, and chickens running around, and Mrs.
Bond here is running around with her hair, trying to keep track of all this and feed everybody, feed the help, you know, in the kitchen.
How much respect did you pay to these people?
So these people held a high level in the community.
Oh, yeah, but this kind of thing is done to your college professor.
Yes, of course.
But I'm trying to assess your level of respect for military heritage for a number of reasons.
One is with what intensity did you go into the military?
With what intensity then did it affect you to find yourself captured?
And with what intensity then did you have to break all those ties?
How deep were those ties that you would have to later amputate?
If you were to meet a military officer now, you wouldn't feel that same respect that you would have felt then, which indicates that the amputation was complete.
So when you met these people, it was nod the head and startles there, because these were fun, so and so.
Yeah.
And I always thought that this kind of behavior was a courtesy kind of thing.
It was not a
It did not say that I was odd, or it did not give anything away from, take not anything away from me as a person.
Oh, yes, right.
That I would bow, just because I bowed from the waist of whichever we were doing it, I don't remember.
I don't mean to say that it means anything more than how deeply ingrained were the traditions that you then had to break.
I grew up with exactly the same philosophy.
were not too hard to break, especially since we had this breakdown of discipline in the camps.
There was already a 50% breakdown.
We were amongst our own kind, and we did not have to salute each other.
So for a couple of years, it was almost nonexistent except to just the frame of the whole thing.
We might salute the American officers, and we give it as just a form of... Military courtesy.
Military courtesy, and it means nothing.
You could just, if you wanted to, go like this afterwards.
Yeah, but you always did.
Yeah.
It's a matter of recognition.
Oh, yeah, I understand.
So, you know, but it's just like once I learned the customs and the forms of greetings in this country,
I'm a social animal that I enjoy doing the social amenities to get along.
I don't want to start a fight just walking into a room.
No, no, no, of course.
Did you see any of your own officers in the camp?
Or your own officers were in a different company?
No, they were in a different company.
They were separated.
So you generally didn't see your own officers.
So there was no discipline involved.
from the outside except either what you offered to the American commanders.
But one sergeant every evening started a meeting about putting up bulletins and war news and things that have to be done on the post.
Yeah, the usual bureaucracy evolves.
People tend to create
paperwork and keep busy with...
But you wouldn't have saluted the sergeant that called the meeting?

If you had to make a report, for instance, like you see now on television, when somebody comes, let's say a speaker is introducing somebody, he'll say this, gives them an introduction, and then he'll turn, and then he'll bow, and it's an animalistic way of ushering the next one in.
So if I say, how many men do you have in your barracks?
I might say, I have 39 men.
And that makes it official.
Right.
If I just say I have 39 men, you might think I'm just guessing.
After the assassination of Hitler's life in July of 1944, the German army introduced the outstretched arms salute.
and made it mandatory for German soldiers.
I didn't know that.
I often wondered when I saw those pictures, and I kept telling Gene, I said, we never... No, there was nothing like that.
I can't believe that.
I said, I have never seen that.
Yeah, it was made mandatory in the camps after July, or at least a lot of the camps adopted that out of sympathy for those close call.
But nothing like that happened at the camp.
There wasn't a high level of political activity after him.
There must not have been, because I just heard it from you.
Because I questioned it in those pictures I saw in your book.
I said, that can't be.
Old camps.
I said, we never did.
And we never saluted without a hat.
You had said that the camps were being separated, that when you'd get transferred, it had to do with affiliations and things that you didn't know at the time.
So maybe some camps got so different from other camps.
Must have been, yeah.
But we had, I know, when I see some of those things, you know, like without a cap, you don't salute at all.
No, not covered.
Let me ask you,
Once you decided to become an officer, you realized that you had to get combat experience in order to be promoted.
So you waited for an opportunity, and there's an opportunity on the bulletin board.
Volunteers wanted for Africa Corps.
I actually came, it was, I think the other way around it was, I finally somehow, they keep probably going through their records.
Yes.
And I have a feeling that somehow somebody fouled up
Because in my soul book, I was once in it as a mason.
And then somebody scratched a line through it and put down student.
Because I was constantly, like I say, nothing ever happened to me.
And they must have gone and taken a sweep.
They probably needed new officer material, and they looked at their records or something, and they said I was appointed officer's candidate, which is K-O-V.
I became a K-O-V. From that time on, you got special training.
Also there in Mannheim?
Yeah, in Mannheim, and then I was sent to the school in Heidelberg, and from there,
Now you, they evaluated you there at the end and then you were assigned to combat and experience.
That was your requisite for being promoted.
And then you saw assignments at African Corps Volunteer Committee?
At the end of the training at Heidelberg.
Then into the African Corps.
Then you were inducted and you went to the African Corps.
Did you have to have special training for that?
No.
It was just another assignment, special uniforms.
So you got special uniforms.
And then you started on your way down Yugoslavia?
Yeah.
Yugoslavia to Athens.
Right.
How did you get to Italy?
Because you saw the port.
I believe after...
I had to be taken off the plane in Crete because of my diarrhea and illness.
This is going down, after going down Yugoslavia?
Going to Athens, Greece, and just a few days until the planes get ready, I guess.
Trying to catch up with Rommel's army at Tobruk.
There you think the battle was already on.
No, we were not told.
We didn't get any newspapers or anything.
You were in Crete.
Yeah, we were in Crete.
And then as soon as I recovered, I'm trying to wreck my memory how I got back to
So quickly, because I didn't take the same freight cattle train back that took forever through Yugoslavia and stuff.
Whether they flew me, I don't think they flew me.
I would have gotten sick again.
Maybe a better train, faster train or something that they got me back and then into a new unit and down to Italy.
Still in the African port.
Still in the African port.
And outside of Naples, while we were waiting again, we got a pass to go to Pompeii and to see the Pope.
Did you go with a bunch of friends, or were you just on your own?
Yeah, a bunch of friends.
It was more of a controlled guided tour.
And you saw Pope Pius XII?
People came out and blessed the crowd and blessed the road.
And I sent it back and I think I would send one to Maria up because I knew she was a good captain.
She would like it.
Also, here's a girl who's building up her expectations.
Not only a weekend in the country, but a blessed rosary on top of it.
No, no.
Sharia?
No, no, no weekend in the country.
Oh, oh.
The other one in that case.
This thing may be, we could sell this to Hustler.
All right, so then from Italy, somehow you were transferred finally down to Toulouse.
Yeah, the Tobruk.
The Tobruk.
East of Tobruk.
You were flown down or went by ship, do you recall?
I believe it was ship and truck.
Ship to North Africa and then truck took you across the desert.
I'm just trying to feel this thing so I don't have any really old periods missing.
Yeah.
Okay, so you're at Tobruk, and then starts the whole process of artillery.
Battle, artillery barrages and stops and new foxholes every night or every other night.
And you're in the retreat.
In a retreat.
It's just a hit-and-run kind of operation.
It was a large unit you were with or a small unit?
The battalion has four guns.
There may have been another battalion nearby.
Mm-hmm.
But everything was fairly stretched out.
Were you ever strafed by?
Oh, constantly, by a P-38 that bombed overhead with these B-52s on their runs.
They came and just rained it down like a...
an orchard of trees, those things come off, you know.
Let me interrupt, but I think that, I'm talking about the P-38, and I think you mentioned that years later, you can serve salad out of it.
Salad out of it.
Oh, yes, that's right.
That plastic, that nose cone.
Yes, I never made that connection.
And all these...
I hadn't made that connection, that's cute.
And all those, oh yeah, and all those WW2 vets, you know, they were the most gracious people in the world.
invited me to their Fourth of July party with this marvelous green salad and a P-38 plastic nose cone.
I asked him, what is this?
You're seeing it from a different perspective.
Yes, yes.
Yeah, with the machine guns going at you, you know, spitting out those bullets.
And I hated that plane.
I recognized it anywhere.
Was the salad good?
The salad was excellent.
California style.
California style.
So you were strafed by planes?
And bombed.
And bombed.
The B-52 bombers that came from nowhere.
You could hardly see them.
They were that high.
But you knew you could hear them come down.
And they would lay down these patterns.
So, and no German fighter plane in the sky to, you know, and very little resistance.
Did you ever get morale lectures from political officers that came around and gave you a pep talk?
Never seen a political officer.
I'm honest, honestly.
Never seen one.
They may have had them.
Yeah, they came around the units to give morale to the men.
Okay, so you are, morale is dropping quickly.
Yes and no.
I think the German, that's one of the things, you know, you just take it.
Then you get kind of stoic.
That's it.
That's the way it is.
And you just go out and do your thing.
Was there a lull and then the surrender?
Or was it a barrage, barrage, barrage, and then the surrender came right after?
Yeah.
Pretty shortly after barrage, yeah.
And finally, somebody had made an arrangement to surrender.
You didn't know who it was?
You didn't have anything to do with it?
As a matter of fact, this particular unit is called Storm Artillery.
My father mentioned it somewhere in this newspaper advertisement that it was attached to a storm artillery, which is slightly different, I think.
I don't think we had any infantry in front of us.
We had nothing, just a desert.
So you just moved around and...
tried to scare the other guy into thinking you were something or you were bigger than you were or whatever.
And I have never, except a gentleman came around, a gentleman came around once, kind of a short guy with a red thing on his pants and, you know, everywhere.
And they're usually feisty little guys.
They have a little pep talk, a little smile, and that kind of thing.
And that's the only guy that ever really... My officer, I never saw him.
They were always up front on some mountain with their radio man.
you know, looking and directing the fire.
That's why we're talking about, you know, this stretched out, this, you know, none of this compression of people, you know.
We didn't have that.
If you looked up, out of your foxhole, you saw absolutely nothing.
Did you make any close army buddies while you were there?
Friends that you may have

Surrendered with and gone to camp with because these kinds of crises bring people together Yeah, someone's shooting at you and there's somebody nearby you get to know that person pretty quickly Yeah, but the thing is you were not allowed in a foxhole with anybody That is pretty strange thing that people I never see that anywhere that this is The most important thing in that kind of warfare and

that you do not have a buddy in your foxhole because i see it in these movies all the time four or five guys that get so close like crime and he thinks it would have been unheard of you were not allowed i see a lot of isolation from from yeah one end to the other even even in your in under fire you were almost yeah i i'm just as interested in what you're saying you know
Because it's not like the pictures from Vietnam where you see two soldiers hugging each other and crying, or mud streaked and bleeding.
This is a very... Yeah, only if somebody was hurt, you know.
Were there a lot of people hurt that you remember?
Not too, no.
Because it had to almost be a direct hit of one foxhole.
If the thing hit 20 or 30 feet away, if you had a decent foxhole, you probably got away with getting a few rocks

thrown at you you know and everything else went about you and you got a new foxhole there and you got a foxhole right from the yeah yeah and it's a good one because they can never hit that spot again yeah yeah they cannot right at least in those days they couldn't tell it's in the rule book somewhere yeah uh how long did this go on
How long, from the time you got to Africa, I can check on the soul book, but about how long do you remember it going on?
About four months, three or four months.
Three or four months in Africa.
Then comes barrages, barrages, barrages, and someone informs you that it's...
just lay low, we're going to surrender, and someone's going to come around for us.
Yeah, and actually, within a day or two, at first I had my orders to report to Berlin, and then within a few hours or a day next,
hold everything.
We were surrounded, cut off.
We are waiting for their orders.
Stay in your foxhole.
So there you are reading that book in your foxhole and donated by the German Red Cross.
By the German Red Cross.
And it's just a lovely, lovely story of hope and love.
You know, man, woman, love.
Very fundamental
thing that I needed at that time.
The humanistic side of people rather than the war, which by that time was gone.
Were you writing to your parents while they were in New England?
I may have, but I doubt if I wrote too much because we were really on the run.
And I was, to be honest with you, I was pretty scared most of the time.
Sure, sure.
I didn't even say anything.
I just think that something is going to, some red hot piece is going to tear you apart and mostly maim you.
Yes.
I was always terrified.
It's amazing, like, you know, in those fragments, you can hear them sing, you know, around after the impact.
Those are the best scary moments.
First, of course, the impact.
And that scares the hell out of you.
But then come the fragment, and that high whine, and you can almost see them red hot.
Oh, yes, yeah.
You know, you can almost visualize them by the sound.
They had to be red-hot steel.
And then you said, Jesus Christ, they're going to take half of one of those buggers.
They're going to tear the nastiest hole into you that you can imagine.
No religious moments at times like that.
Those are the moments when you start probing your values and religious, making deals with God, as my mother does when my brother's orders came through.
Do you remember any...
sitting there doing the catechism, or sitting there and... My reaction to something like that is, who in the hell screwed this whole thing up?
To get us into that kind of... How can that ever be?
That sounds pretty sane to me.
Who is doing this?
Let me ask, when you went to school, when you were in school, before you went into the service,
What were your best subjects, do you recall?
English.
German second, maybe.
And of course, athletics.
Mathematics.
Math also, second.
So I was pretty much of an A minus.
Right.
Pretty much across sometimes straight As, but not very often.
There's always a minus here and there.
And did you finish?
I went to the Obersekunde when I had diphtheria.
And I was out of school for all year.
Which is why you couldn't become an officer going directly from school.
Yeah, right, going directly from school.
And I could not catch up with the class after me because they had now French, and they had changed the curriculum behind me without asking me.
Because if it had been the same curriculum, all I had to do was do it over again.
Right.
and catch up for that one year.
And I only missed it by, I remember my gym teacher said, Dennis, if I'd known that...
He didn't say Dennis, but let's go with that.
He took me aside, we were doing broad jumps that day, and my physical ability wasn't, I was below my distances and everything, falling off from sickness a little bit, but I was coming back.
If I'd known it was that close, we could have done something, you know, he said, you know.
So dropped out that last year.
Yeah.
Not unlike your dropping out last year, so.
Yeah.
Yeah, and then my father wanted that we tried that class and simply could not.
It wasn't only that they had French as a major, they seemed to have a hold of math and everything had changed.
From about, they had gotten a new direction and it's just a different curriculum.
And I always was so jealous of
of the American school system when I heard that you had your units and what you had, you kept.
All you had to do is go somewhere else and make up what you didn't have.
That made so much more sense.
Yeah.
I paid $2 for the fingertips.
Let me ask you, as close as it was, could your father not have pulled some strings?
I get the feeling your father was a very important man in town.
Yes.
He's a Eisenbahnmeister or that was.
Yeah, but he was gone so much on his train.
He had odd hours, sometimes overnight trips.
So he wasn't really that powerful.
In fact, now that you've mentioned it, it's a good point.
You're very intuitive.
Because I was really a little upset with my father for not doing something and checking up on it.
that I was in this no-win situation and was having difficulties.
And of course, maybe it may have been my fault.
I didn't communicate enough.
I don't know.
But you certainly thought he was powerful enough to be able to do something.
Yeah, yeah.
He says, if we had had some conferences, maybe with some of the teachers, we could have ironed out something about this.
And we did have a talk, if I remember exactly.
And then he said, well, I'm sorry, or something to that effect.
But I said, no, no on that.
And I said, well, what are we going to do now?
OK, then how about trying to, there was a nearby town that, at that time,
It was more similar, he thought, but it had girls in it, co-ed school in a town maybe 20, 30 miles away.
And I tried that, and they had a curriculum that I didn't fit too well, did not make it.
Then he said we'd go.
